title: Meckel’s Diverticulum Bleeding
diagnosis_topic: Ectopic gastric mucosa in Meckel’s diverticulum causing painless lower GI bleeding
setup_script: “A 2-year-old boy presents with passage of bright red stools for one day. He is otherwise active and has no abdominal pain or fever. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “Maroon and blood-tinged stools with no mucus; digital rectal exam confirms blood without fissures.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CBC and type and cross
dynamic_flow.reply: “Hemoglobin 9 g/dL, platelets normal; blood bank prepares units for transfusion.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates IV fluids and keeps NPO
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient stabilizes hemodynamically while awaiting further management.”
“Pediatric surgery evaluates the patient for operative intervention.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident requests technetium-99m pertechnetate (Meckel) scan
dynamic_flow.reply: “Uptake in the right lower quadrant consistent with ectopic gastric mucosa.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays intervention and bleeding continues
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient becomes hypotensive with BP 75/40, HR 140, requiring blood transfusion.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds with operative intervention
dynamic_flow.reply: “Laparoscopic diverticulectomy is performed, and the bleeding diverticulum is excised.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about intraoperative findings
dynamic_flow.reply: “A 2.5 cm Meckel’s diverticulum with ulcerated ectopic gastric mucosa is identified.”
“Patient resumes feeds once bowel function returns; vitals remain stable.”
“Explains cause, surgical procedure, and low risk of recurrence.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for associated anomalies
dynamic_flow.reply: “Consider screening for other omphalomesenteric duct remnants or malrotation.”

critical_decision_points: Evaluation of painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding in children
Use of Meckel scan to detect ectopic gastric mucosa
Resuscitation and surgical removal of Meckel’s diverticulum
Recognition of ongoing bleeding necessitating transfusion and urgent surgery

resident_feedback_template: Strengths:You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by identifying Meckel’s diverticulum as a likely source of painless GI bleeding. You appropriately ordered confirmatory testing and coordinated operative management. Communication with the team and family was clear and structured.Areas for Improvement:Earlier recognition of the hemodynamic instability and timely transfusion planning could be improved. Consider broadening the differential diagnosis when the Meckel scan is negative to include other causes of lower GI bleeding in children.Suggested Reading Topics:- Pediatric Lower GI Bleeding (SCORE Curriculum)- Meckel’s Diverticulum and Omphalomesenteric Duct Anomalies (ASE Core Curriculum)- Perioperative Management in Pediatric Surgery (ACS/ASE Review Manual)
